awd_titl_txt: MRI: Acquisition of a Tip-Enhanced Nano Raman Spectroscopy (TERS) Microscope for Soft Matter Research and Education
awd_abstract_narration:
This project is jointly funded by the Major Research Instrumentation (MRI) and the Established Program to Stimulate Competitive Research (EPSCoR).

Non-Technical Description:
The acquisition of a tip-enhanced nano-Raman spectroscopy instrument at the University of Vermont (UVM) will create a nexus for convergent materials research, addressing fundamental cross-disciplinary questions related to chemical behavior and structure-properties relationships in materials ranging from large biomolecules and organic small-molecule semiconductors to geological formations and minerals. Recent investments by UVM in the Science, Technology, Engineering and Mathematics building complex, including a shared microscopy research laboratory space, have created an effective location for the instrument, which is operated as part of a user research facility. UVM has a group of cross-disciplinary researchers with expertise and scientific interests that make full use of the instrument, while simultaneously attracting regional collaborators. The microscope is incorporated into an advanced two-semester instrumentation Materials Science (MATS) course for graduate and undergraduate students. High school and middle school students learn about the research enabled by this instrument through events organized in collaboration with the student-led local chapter of the Materials Research Society.

Technical Description:
Tip-enhanced Raman spectroscopy is a new technique that facilitates rapid advances in exploring complex soft and hard materials systems because it enables simultaneous multi-imaging techniques with high spatial resolution. The characteristics of the instrument include less than 10 nm spatial resolution and the ability to measure ultra-low frequency Raman shifts. Using this microscope, UVM researchers address one of the greatest challenges of soft matter research: reliably and efficiently mapping the structure-property relationships at small scales, which can ultimately lead to predicting, controlling and tailoring advanced carbon-based materials for specific uses. Research thrusts significantly benefiting from this instrument include a) probing and controlling the coupling between collective dynamics (phonons) and electronic transport in organic semiconductors, b) fundamental understanding of the coupling between vibrations and coherence phenomena in soft matter systems, and c) mapping strain and disorder of thin films on the nanoscale.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
This Major Instrumentation award enabled the purchase and installation of a state-of-the-art tip-enhanced Raman spectrometer in the Departments of Chemistry and Physics at the University of Vermont, which represents a cross-college endeavor from the fundamental natural sciences and applied engineering sciences. This advanced piece of instrumentation allows for studying atomic-scale phenomena with both spatial and spectral resolution, on the order of nanometers, which has been applied to a trans-disciplinary array of research ranging from biomedical to plant and soil sciences. Despite challenges associated with the COVID-19 pandemic, the instrument was successfully installed, and a wide user-base was trained, consisting of undergradaute and graduate students, early-career researchers, professors, and industry professionals - both from the University of Vermont and institutions in the greater New England region. The TERS system was instrumental in recruiting new faculty members, and through that process the University of Vermont was able to increase it faculty diversity by hiring from underrepresented groups. The instrument was incorporated into undergradaute practical laboratory courses, which serves to train the next generation of STEM professionals in the use of a new and advanced technique that is not common in standard undergraduate coursework. Importantly, the instrument is modular, and since the original purchase it has had its capabilities improved by various faculty members' upgrades, including a third laser source and advanced optics. The instrument has been used in an enormously cross-disciplinary manner, and early results have provided insights into a number of critical areas. For example, research enabled by the TERS instrument has yielded considerable insight into the nature of interactions in gene-therapy tools, providing a foundation for new therapeutics. In another work, this system was used to understand the formation of molecular crystals, which have applications in solar cells and advanced photovoltaics. The instrument has also been used to analyze plant and soil samples, in order to monitor toxic chemical buildup from agricultural runoff. Moving forward, the TERS system has a long life ahead, and it will continue to be used to increase the impact of fundamental science at the University of Vermont - and the greater economic region.
